collections.title: The effects of ginger supplementation on metabolic profiles in people with type 2 diabetes and comorbidities.
collections.text: Ginger supplementation reduced fasting blood glucose, glycated hemoglobin, and blood pressure in participants with type 2 diabetes. Ginger supplementation reduced fasting blood glucose, glycated hemoglobin.

content.quotation: In this meta-analysis of prospective cohort studies, higher intakes of several flavonoid subclasses (anthocyanins, proanthocyanidins, flavonols, flavones, and isoflavones) were associated with a lower risk of coronary heart disease.

background.p: Flavonoids are a class of polyphenolic compounds found in a large number of plants, many of which are regularly consumed by humans. Flavonoids can be categorized into various subclasses, which include flavonols, flavones, flavan-3-ols, anthocyanins, flavanones, and isoflavones.

Higher total flavonoid intake has been associated with a lower risk of coronary heart disease (CHD).[21] However, this doesn’t necessarily mean that all flavonoid subclasses have the exact same effects on the risk of CHD. This meta-analysis of prospective cohorts looked at the association between CHD and specific flavonoid subclasses

study: This meta-analysis of 19 prospective cohort studies examined the association between various flavonoid subclasses and risk of CHD events using data from 894,471 participants. The included studies had follow-up periods ranging from 3.1 to 28 years, during which time 34,707 CHD events occurred.

The researchers assessed the following individual flavonoid subclasses: anthocyanins (8 studies), proanthocyanidins (4 studies), flavones (7 studies), isoflavones (6 studies), flavanones (8 studies), flavan-3-ols (6 studies), and flavonols (8 studies). They also looked at 3 specific flavonols: quercetin (6 studies), kaempferol (5 studies), and myricetin (5 studies).

The researchers compared the CHD risk associated with the highest and lowest intake of individual flavonoids. They also performed dose-response analyses to determine if there was a linear relationship between flavonoid dose and CHD risk.
result: Comparing low-intake participants to high-intake participants resulted in the following findings:

Anthocyanins were associated with a 10% lower risk of CHD events, proanthocyanidins with a 22% lower risk, flavonols with a 12% lower risk, flavones with a 6% lower risk, and isoflavones with a 10% lower risk. The association between flavanones and flavan-3-ols did not reach statistical significance. There was likewise no statistically significant association between individual flavonols (i.e., quercetin, kaempferol, and myricetin) and risk of CHD.

In a dose-response analysis, the dosages associated with a 5% reduction in CHD risk were: 50 mg of anthocyanins, 100 mg of proanthocyanidins, 25 mg of flavonols, 5 mg of flavones, and 0.5 mg of isoflavones.
One study was classified as medium quality and 18 studies were classified as high quality.

lists.title: A 2021 meta-analysis found that proanthocyanidins reduced blood pressure.
lists.hover: A 2021 meta-analysis found that proanthocyanidins reduced blood pressure.

lists.title: A 2017 meta-analysis found that flavonols lowered blood pressure and fasting glucose and increased HDL.
lists.hover: A 2017 meta-analysis found that flavonols lowered blood pressure and fasting glucose and increased HDL.

lists.title: A 2018 meta-analysis found that anthocyanins lowered LDL and ApoB and increased HDL,[24] and a 2020 meta-analysis found that anthocyanins reduced the inflammatory markers CRP, IL-6, and TNF-α.
lists.hover: A 2018 meta-analysis found that anthocyanins lowered LDL and ApoB and increased HDL,[24] and a 2020 meta-analysis found that anthocyanins reduced the inflammatory markers CRP, IL-6, and TNF-α.

lists.hover: Isoflavones were found to lower blood pressure in people with hypertension in a 2012 meta-analysis[26] and improve arterial stiffness in a 2021 meta-analysis.

lists.title: AFlavones have not been the subject of nearly as much clinical research as other flavonoids in terms of their effect on cardiovascular risk factors.
lists.hover: AFlavones have not been the subject of nearly as much clinical research as other flavonoids in terms of their effect on cardiovascular risk factors.

content.quotation: In this meta-analysis of prospective cohort studies, higher intakes of several flavonoid subclasses (anthocyanins, proanthocyanidins, flavonols, flavones, and isoflavones) were associated with a lower risk of coronary heart disease.

background.p: Flavonoids are a class of polyphenolic compounds found in a large number of plants, many of which are regularly consumed by humans. Flavonoids can be categorized into various subclasses, which include flavonols, flavones, flavan-3-ols, anthocyanins, flavanones, and isoflavones.

Higher total flavonoid intake has been associated with a lower risk of coronary heart disease (CHD).[21] However, this doesn’t necessarily mean that all flavonoid subclasses have the exact same effects on the risk of CHD. This meta-analysis of prospective cohorts looked at the association between CHD and specific flavonoid subclasses

study: This meta-analysis of 19 prospective cohort studies examined the association between various flavonoid subclasses and risk of CHD events using data from 894,471 participants. The included studies had follow-up periods ranging from 3.1 to 28 years, during which time 34,707 CHD events occurred.

The researchers assessed the following individual flavonoid subclasses: anthocyanins (8 studies), proanthocyanidins (4 studies), flavones (7 studies), isoflavones (6 studies), flavanones (8 studies), flavan-3-ols (6 studies), and flavonols (8 studies). They also looked at 3 specific flavonols: quercetin (6 studies), kaempferol (5 studies), and myricetin (5 studies).

The researchers compared the CHD risk associated with the highest and lowest intake of individual flavonoids. They also performed dose-response analyses to determine if there was a linear relationship between flavonoid dose and CHD risk.
result: Comparing low-intake participants to high-intake participants resulted in the following findings:

Anthocyanins were associated with a 10% lower risk of CHD events, proanthocyanidins with a 22% lower risk, flavonols with a 12% lower risk, flavones with a 6% lower risk, and isoflavones with a 10% lower risk. The association between flavanones and flavan-3-ols did not reach statistical significance. There was likewise no statistically significant association between individual flavonols (i.e., quercetin, kaempferol, and myricetin) and risk of CHD.

In a dose-response analysis, the dosages associated with a 5% reduction in CHD risk were: 50 mg of anthocyanins, 100 mg of proanthocyanidins, 25 mg of flavonols, 5 mg of flavones, and 0.5 mg of isoflavones.
One study was classified as medium quality and 18 studies were classified as high quality.
